Module WitchHunt
Package fr.sos.witchhunt.model.players

Class Player

java.lang.Object
fr.sos.witchhunt.model.players.Player
All Implemented Interfaces:
PlayerDisplayRequester, Resettable, Visitable
Direct Known Subclasses:
CPUPlayer, HumanPlayer
public abstract class Player extends Object implements PlayerDisplayRequester, Resettable, Visitable

This abstract class defines common behavior and specifies required abstract methods for both human and CPU players.

A player has a unique name (chosen at the start of a match human players), and a unique id, which is auto-incremented.

Players are added at the start of the match by an instance of Tabletop.

They have an identity, which is determined by their card (which can be revealed or not).

They also possess a hand containing plural Rumour cards, which can also be revealed or not.

They can be active, or not if they were eliminated or if they are not part of a tied game's last round.

All abstract methods within this class must be defined with different bodies by the classes representing human and CPU players

They implement Resettable and are reset at the end of each round.

They also implement Visitable, which makes them a possible target for classes implementing Visitor. The score they obtained at each round is saved by an instance of ScoreCounter, using the Visitor design pattern.

Their display requests are passed to an instance of a class implementing DisplayMediator. They themselves implement PlayerDisplayRequester, which specifies all types of display requests they can need.

See Also:
  • HumanPlayer
  • CPUPlayer
  • identity
  • Visitable
  • Resettable
  • PlayerDisplayRequester
  • DisplayMediator

  • Field Details

    • name

      protected String name
      A player's name, unique in the game.

    • id

      protected int id
      The player's id, unique in the game and auto-incremented.

    • score

      protected int score

      The player's current score.

      A player can score points by accusing a player and making them reveal they are a witch, winRound() by remaining the last unrevealed one. They can also earn or loose points thanks to the Hunt! effects of certain Rumour cards.

      A player can win the round if they are leading with score >= 5.

      Updated exclusively using method addScore(int), which also accepts a visit from the score counter to update the latter one.

      The player's score is not reset between two rounds ! Thus, it isn't affected by the reset() method.

      See Also:
      • addScore(int)
      • accuse(Player)
      • winRound()
      • ScoreCounter
      • ScoreCounter::visit(Player)
      • Visitable
      • ScoreCounter::getPotentialWinners()
      • ScoreCounter::getRanking()

    • identity

      protected Identity identity

      The player's identity, either Witch or Villager. It is always equal to that associated to the player's Identity card.

      Chosen at the start of each round.

      If a player is revealed as a Witch, they are eliminated.

      See Also:
      • Identity
      • identityCard
      • revealIdentity()
      • chooseIdentity()

    • identityCard

      protected IdentityCard identityCard

      The player's Identity card. Associated to the player when they are instantiated, for the whole duration of the match.

      Can be revealed or unrevealed.

      Linked to the player's identity attribute.

      Reset when the player is reset() themselves.

      Chosen at the start of each round.

      See Also:
      • IdentityCard
      • identity
      • revealIdentity()
      • chooseIdentity()
      • reset()
      • Resettable

    • hand

      protected RumourCardsPile hand

      The player's hand, containing Rumour cards, is an instance of RumourCardsPile.

      These cards can be revealed or not.

      The player can use a card on their turn, by triggering its Hunt! effect, of when defending against an accusation, by triggering its Witch? effect.

      Some of these effects can lead the player to discarding, stealing, or taking back cards, thus modifying their hand.

      The player's hand is reset when they get reset() themselves, resetting all Rumour cards it contains and returning them to the game's list of existing cards.

      See Also:
      • getRevealedSubhand()
      • getUnrevealedSubhand()
      • showHand(boolean)
      • discard(RumourCard)
      • takeRumourCard(RumourCard, Player)
      • RumourCardsPile::reset()
      • reset()
      • Resettable
      • RumourCardsPile
      • RumourCard

    • forcedToAccuseBy

      private Player forcedToAccuseBy

      A reference to an adversary forcing the player to accuse someone else on their turn.

      Indeed, the Evil Eye Rumour card can be used by a player to enforce an adversary to accuse any player but them the next turn.

      See Also:
      • forceToAccuseNextTurn(Player)
      • EvilEye
      • immunized
      • accuse(Player)

    • immunized

      private boolean immunized

      When this boolean is true, this player can not be targetted by an accusation.

      Indeed, the Evil Eye Rumour card can be used by a player to enforce an adversary to accuse any player but them the next turn.

      See Also:
      • EvilEye
      • forcedToAccuseBy
      • immunize()

    • active

      private boolean active

      When this boolean is false, the player is out of the current round.

      This can happen either when the player gets eliminate() eliminated, or when the player is not part of the last round of a tied game.

      This boolean is set back to true at the end of each round, when the player gets reset().

      See Also:
      • eliminate()
      • eliminate(Player)
      • reset()
      • Tabletop::getActivePlayersList()

    • displayMediator

      protected DisplayMediator displayMediator

      The players are associated with an instance of a class implementing DisplayMediator

      The players passes every display request they have to this object, which is responsible of organizing their display.

      This field is binded at the player's creation.

      See Also:
      • DisplayMediator
      • PlayerDisplayRequester

    • shortDelay

      private int shortDelay

      Adds a little delay before sending certain display notifications to the view.

      Expressed in milliseconds.

  • Constructor Details

    • Player

      public Player(String name, int id)

      Instanciates a player with a given name and a given id.

      Also initializes their IdentityCard, as well as their hand.

      Parameters:
      name - The pseudonym given to this player. Will be used in the display.
      id - An integer identifying the player. Unicity must be ensured.
      See Also:
      • HumanPlayer(String, int)

    • Player

      public Player(int id)

      Instanciates a player with a given id.

      Their name has to be generated automatically.

      Also initializes their IdentityCard, as well as their hand.

      Parameters:
      id - An integer identifying the player. Unicity must be ensured.
      See Also:
      • CPUPlayer(int, int)

  • Method Details

    • chooseIdentity

      public abstract void chooseIdentity()
      Chooses and sets the player's identity and that of their identityCard. Based on user-input for human players, chosen by artificial intelligence for CPUplayers.
      See Also:

    • revealIdentity

      public Identity revealIdentity()
      Reveals the player's identityCard and returns their identity. Requests display of this event.
      Returns:
      The player's identity
      See Also:
      • Identity
      • Identity card

    • forcedReveal

      public Identity forcedReveal()

      Reveals the player's identityCard and returns their identity.

      Requests the display of a specific message implying the player has been forced to do so. Different from revealIdentity() only by the display. Can happen when there are no playable witch effects left, or when a Hunt! effect forces the player to reveal their identity.

      Returns:
      The player's identity
      See Also:
      • revealIdentity()
      • canWitch()

    • chooseTurnAction

      public abstract TurnAction chooseTurnAction()

      Chooses an action to perform during the player's turn.

      Based on user input for human players, done by artificial intelligence for CPUPlayers.

      Returns:
      The selected action : TurnAction can be either ACCUSE or HUNT.
      See Also:
      • TurnAction
      • accuse(Player)
      • hunt()
      • HumanPlayer.chooseTurnAction()
      • CPUPlayer.chooseTurnAction()

    • playTurn

      public void playTurn()

      Called when it is the player's turn.

      Causes the player to choose an action to perform and executes it.

      Requests display of a message indicating it is the player's turn.

      In the special situation where the player has been forced to accuse an adversary by the Evil Eye Rumour card, the player is directly asked to accuse an opponent.

      See Also:
      • TurnAction
      • accuse(Player)
      • hunt()
      • forcedToAccuseBy

    • chooseNextPlayer

      public abstract Player chooseNextPlayer()

      Elects the player who is going to take the next turn.

      Based on user-input for human players, chosen by artificial intelligence for CPUplayers.

      Called by certain Rumour cards' effects, like the Ducking Stool's Witch? effect for example.

      Returns:
      The Player who was chosen to take the next turn
      See Also:
      • takeNextTurn()
      • HumanPlayer.chooseNextPlayer()
      • CPUPlayer.chooseNextPlayer()
      • Round.setNextPlayer(Player)

    • takeNextTurn

      public void takeNextTurn()

      Elects this player to play the next turn.

      Requests for the display of a suitable notification : if it was not already this player's turn, only notifies the view that this player takes the next turn, otherwise, notifies the view that this player is taking again another turn.

      No display if the round is over (only one unrevealed player).

      See Also:
      • Round::setNextPlayer(Player)

    • winRound

      public void winRound()

      The player wins the current round as they are the last whose identity wasn't revealed.

      Lets them score 2 points if they were playing as a Witch, or 1 point if they were playing as a Villager.

      If another round is to be played, this player will start.

      See Also:
      • addScore(int)
      • Tabletop::setLastUnrevealedPlayer
      • Identity
      • isRevealed()
      • Round

    • accuse

      public void accuse(Player p)

      Accuses another player of practicing witchcraft.

      Requests a display for this event.

      Calls the defend() method on the target, allowing them to choose between revealing their identity and playing the witch effect of a Rumour card in their hand.

      If the target could keep their identity hidden, their defend() method returns null and nothing happens. Else, it returns the value of their identity. If the target was revealed as a Villager, the target takes the next turn. Otherwise, if the target was revealed as a Witch, the accusing player earns 1 point and eliminates their target.

      Parameters:
      p - The player to accuse.
      See Also:
      • Tabletop::setAccusator(Player)
      • Tabletop::setAccusedPlayer(Player)
      • Identity
      • defend()
      • chooseDefenseAction()
      • DefenseAction
      • takeNextTurn()
      • addScore(int)
      • eliminate(Player)

    • accuse

      See Also:

    • choosePlayerToAccuse

      protected abstract Player choosePlayerToAccuse()

      Chooses a player to accuse

      Based on user-input for human players, chosen by artificial intelligence for CPUplayers.
      Returns:
      A reference pointing towards the selected target.
      See Also:

      • CPUPlayer.choosePlayerToAccuse()

    • chooseDefenseAction

      public abstract DefenseAction chooseDefenseAction()

      Chooses an action to respond to an accusation or a Hunt! effect.

      When a player is accused, they can choose between playing a Witch? effect, if they can, and revealing their identity.

      When a player is targetted by certain Hunt! effect like that of DuckingStool, they can choose between revealing their identity and discarding one of their Rumour cards.

      Based on user-input for human players, chosen by artificial intelligence for CPUplayers.
      Returns:
      A response among ACCUSE, REVEAL and DISCARD.
      See Also:
      • DefenseAction
      • revealIdentity()
      • witch()
      • discard(RumourCard)
      • revealOrDiscard()
      • HumanPlayer.chooseDefenseAction()
      • CPUPlayer.chooseDefenseAction()

    • defend

      public Identity defend()
      Respond to an accusation, revealing the player's identity or playing a Witch? effect. If the player has no cards with playable witch effects left, they are forcedReveal() forced to reveal their identity.
      Returns:
      The accused player's disclosed identity, if they revealed it. Otherwise, null.
      See Also:
      • Identity
      • accuse(Player)
      • chooseDefenseAction()
      • canWitch()
      • witch()
      • revealIdentity()
      • forcedReveal()

    • discard

      public void discard(RumourCard rc)

      Sends a Rumour card from the player's hand to the pile.

      Requests for a display of this event.

      Caused by certain Rumour cards' effects, like the Hunt! effect of the Ducking Stool.

      Parameters:
      rc - A Rumour card coming from the player's hand.
      See Also:
      • Rumour card
      • RumourCardsPile::giveCard(RumourCard, RumourCardsPile)
      • Tabletop::getPile()
      • DuckingStool

    • discard

      public void discard()
      Selects a Rumour card to discard from the player's hand and discards it.
      See Also:
      • selectCardToDiscard()
      • discard(RumourCard)

      public void discard(RumourCardsPile in)

      See Also:
      • selectCardToDiscard(RumourCardsPile)

    • discardRandomCard

      public void discardRandomCard()

      Discards a random card from the player's hand.

      Caused by certain Rumour cards' effects, like the Witch? effect of Cauldron.

      Requests for the display of a suitable message if the player has no cards left.

      See Also:
      • discard(RumourCard)
      • Cauldron

    • chooseAnyCard

      public abstract RumourCard chooseAnyCard(RumourCardsPile from, boolean seeUnrevealedCards)
      Chooses a card (revealed or not) within a pile of cards. Based on user-input for human players, chosen by artificial intelligence for CPUplayers.
      Parameters:
      from - The pile of Rumour cards within which a card must be chosen.
      seeUnrevealedCards - If this boolean is true, unrevealed cards will be shown as if they were not.
      Returns:
      The chosen Rumour card.
      See Also:
      • RumourCardsPile
      • RumourCard
      • HumanPlayer.chooseAnyCard(RumourCardsPile, boolean)
      • CPUPlayer.chooseAnyCard(RumourCardsPile, boolean)

    • revealOrDiscard

      public abstract DefenseAction revealOrDiscard()
      Chooses an action between revealing your identity and discarding a Rumour card from your hand. Called when targetted by the Ducking Stool card's Hunt! effect.
      Returns:
      Either DefenseAction.REVEAL or DefenseAction.DISCARD
      See Also:

      Parameters:

    • reset

      public void reset()

      Resets some of the player's attributes to their initial states.

      Called after the end of each round by class Tabletop.

      The player's identity is set back to null and their Identity card is reset. Their hand is also reset. The player becomes active again.

      Specified by:
      reset in interface Resettable
      See Also:
      • Resettable
      • identity
      • identityCard
      • resetting an Identity card
      • hand
      • resetting an instance of RumourCardsPile
      • active
      • Tabletop

    • requestIdentityRevealScreen

      public void requestIdentityRevealScreen()

      Sends a notification informing the view that the player is going to display their identity.

      Then, simulates a delay depending on the player's identity (longer for a witch).

      Finally, sends the notification informing the view that it has to display the screen corresponding to the player's identity reveal.

      Specified by:
      requestIdentityRevealScreen in interface PlayerDisplayRequester
      See Also:
      • DisplayMediator.displayIdentityRevealScreen(Player,Player)
      • revealIdentity()

    • isImmunizedAgainstRumourCard

      public boolean isImmunizedAgainstRumourCard(RumourCard rc)
      Certain Rumour cards can immunize a player against other Rumour cards. Example : the Wart card grants immunity against the Ducking Stool card, once it has been revealed.
      Parameters:
      rc - The Rumour card against which we test whether the player is immunized or not.
      Returns:
      true if the player is immunized against this card, false otherwise.
      See Also:
      • RumourCard.grantsImmunityAgainst(RumourCard)
      • Wart
      • Broomstick

    • addScore

      public void addScore(int pts)

      Adds the given number of points to the player's score and notifies the score counter of a change in the player's score using the accept(Visitor) method.

      @param pts The number of points by which the player's score is updated (can be negative, as some cards can make a player loose points)

      Requests for the display of a suitable notification.

      A player can score by accusing or hunting their opponents, or by being the round's last unrevealed player.

      Parameters:
      pts - The number of points by which the player's score should be updated
      See Also:
      • score
      • Visitable
      • accept(Visitor)
      • ScoreCounter.visit(Player)
      • accuse()
      • hunt()
      • winRound()
      • Tabletop.getLastUnrevealedPlayer()

    • clearImmunities

      private void clearImmunities()
      Removes everyone's immunity after an accusation Called at the end of the accuse() method, as the immunity is supposed to be only one-use.
      See Also:
      • immunized
      • accuse()
      • looseImmunity()

    • canHunt

      protected boolean canHunt()
      Tests if the player has unrevealed cards with a playable Hunt! effect in their hand.

      Indirectly calls the HuntEffect::isAllowed() method, which requires the player to be as the "currently hunting player" at the scale of the game.

      Returns:
      true if the player can play a Hunt! effect.
      See Also:
      • RumourCardsPile::getPlayableHuntSubpile()
      • HuntEffect
      • HuntEffect::isAllowed()
      • chooseTurnAction()
      • Tabletop::setHunter(Player)

    • canWitch

      public boolean canWitch()
      Tests if the player has unrevealed cards with a playable Witch? effect in their hand.

      Calls the HuntEffect::isAllowed() method.

      Indirectly calls the WitchEffect::isAllowed() method, which requires the player to be as the "current accusator" at the scale of the game.

      Returns:
      true if the player can play a Witch? effect.
      See Also:
      • RumourCardsPile::getPlayableWitchSubpile()
      • WitchEffect
      • WitchEffect::isAllowed()
      • defend()
      • Tabletop::setAccusator(Player)
